div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to John J. Moran, April 10, 1928
div1.p:
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON
PRESIDENT
COL. FREDERICK H. VINUP
MEDICAL CORPS, MARYLAND NATIONAL GUARD
FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
SENIOR SURGEON C. H. LAVINDER
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
SECOND VICE-PRESIDENT
BRIGADIER GENERAL WM. H. WILMER
MEDICAL RESERVE CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
EDITOR AND SECRETARY
COL. JEFFERSON R. KEAN
UNITED STATES ARMY, RET.
THIRD VICE-PRESIDENT
CAPT. JAMES C. PRYOR
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES NAVY
FOURTH VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES R. REYNOLDS
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
ASSISTANT EDITOR
MAJOR EDGAR ERSKINE HUME
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE MILITARY SURGEON
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
SEVENTH AND B STREETS S. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
10 April, 1928 Mr. John J. Moran,
c/o Firestone Tire Company,
Akron, Ohio.
My dear Mr. Moran:

It has been many years since we have seen each other, and
I did not even know your address until it was given me by Mr.
Charles Parker whom you will remember as hospital steward at
Las Animas hospital at the time of the Walter Reed yellow fever
work.

The question of adequate recognition by the National
Government for the widows of the members of the Commission
who are dead, for Dr. Aristides Agramonte, who is the only
surviving member, and for those who volunteered to submit to
the experiments, among whom I regard you as the leading spirit,
has recently been brought forward by Professor James E. Peabody
and a group of public spirited men in New York.

I am going with the Surgeon General to a hearing on this
subject tomorrow before the Military Committee of the House. My
object in writing to you is, in the first place, to get your
address and get in touch with you. We are making an effort to get
in touch with as many as possible of the 18 Americans who submitted
to the mosquito and fomites experiments. Therefore, I would like
to hear from you and to have your address. I imagine this through
the Firestone Tire Company is rather a round about way of reaching
you.

Sincerely yours,
J.R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.

P. S. April 20, 1928.
My dear Mr. Moran:

This letter has been returned from the Firestone
Tire Company stating that you are not on their rolls. Mr. Charles
Parker whom you knew in Panama and who is now the Chief Clerk of the
Army Medical Library, has given me your address with the Mexican
Trading Corporation to which I am now addressing this letter. Please
let me hear from you promptly as I am trying to get the addresses of
all the men who took part in the yellow fever experiments of the Reed
Board. The Military Committee has recommended a bill giving an
annuity of $3,000 a year to these men. Whether it will go through
Congress or not remains to be seen. I am afraid they will hardly
make as liberal a provision as the Committee recommends but I think,
it would be a splendid thing if they did so. I have tried to impress
the Committee with your fine and disinterested
attitude in this famous episode

Sincerely,
J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor.
